issueDTO.title: Run Helm unit-tests with `-shuffle=on` and `-count=n` (n > 1)
issueDTO.description:
`go test` by default runs unit tests once in a deterministic order.  Leading to:
1. deterministic order: tests relying on their order of execution to pass
2. running once: higher probability of flakey tests passing

Helm's unit tests have encountered both problems lately. Tests relying on running in a particular order, or being flakey.

Adding `-shuffle=on` and `-count=n` (for `n > 1`; perhaps 2 or 3, TBD) will improve these behaviors:

> -count n
	    Run each test, benchmark, and fuzz seed n times (default 1).
	    If -cpu is set, run n times for each GOMAXPROCS value.
	    Examples are always run once. -count does not apply to
	    fuzz tests matched by -fuzz.

> -shuffle off,on,N
	    Randomize the execution order of tests and benchmarks.
	    It is off by default. If -shuffle is set to on, then it will seed
	    the randomizer using the system clock. If -shuffle is set to an
	    integer N, then N will be used as the seed value. In both cases,
	    the seed will be reported for reproducibility.

https://pkg.go.dev/cmd/go/internal/test
comments: Note: https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/30610 attempted to enable `-shuffle=on`. But immediately found tests which failed when run in random order.
can I work on this?

@7h3-3mp7y-m4n if you want I started working on this. But feel free to continue, it's still flaky. :) 

https://github.com/helm/helm/compare/main...benoittgt:helm:shuffle-test?expand=1

It's alright @benoittgt , it's all yours ;)
All the best :)

Careful if you work on this. It appears it breaks the Mac OS keychain. I had 3 settings wipe since yesterday, and it appears that the issue is happening to a test close to `TestTLSRegistryClientTestSuite/Test_4_Logout`. It calls [this in oras](https://github.com/oras-project/oras-go/blob/05a2b09cbf2eab1df691411884dc4df741ec56ab/registry/remote/credentials/registry.go#L63-L65) behind. I've lost some data settings in the battle.
For anyone who has a PR for this please take me and gjenkins8 we will be happy to review.
can i work on this??

@gjenkins8 Moving to `-count=2` adds about 2.5 minutes to the test run time in CI. It adds a bunch of time to the local test runs, too. This impacts the inner loop on development. What do we gain by doing this? It is worth it?

I noted this over at https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/31013#pullrequestreview-2975837738, too.

> [@gjenkins8](https://github.com/gjenkins8) Moving to `-count=2` adds about 2.5 minutes to the test run time in CI. It adds a bunch of time to the local test runs, too. This impacts the inner loop on development. What do we gain by doing this? It is worth it?
> 
> I noted this over at [#31013 (review)](https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/31013#pullrequestreview-2975837738), too.

The benefit is it will help prevent issues like https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/31016 :)

Yes, the downside is slower test runs. The trade-off being higher confidence we have no flakes.

I  think we can keep local test runs (by default) to continue to run with `-count=1` (the default) ie. `make unit-test`. And so no changes for local dev.

But given the frequency of flakey test runs, I do think it is worth it to run CI with `-count=2`. It will slow CI down, but flakey/buggy tests will likely fail checks. And if we have access to bigger build workers(?), I think that would help reduce the time (bigger workers = more CPUs = more tests running in parallel).

(ill put this comment on https://github.com/helm/helm/pull/31013#pullrequestreview-2975837738 as well)

The final option would be to only run with a higher count upon merging to main. If we really don't want to impact CI times by this much. Thoughts?

issueDTO.title: Question about LAM stage 2 didn't use text encoder
issueDTO.description:
I know there are some instructions in the paper that in stage1 the tasks are already decoupled, but the question is, why? Why doesn't LAM stage 2 have a text encoder? What if I want to do some further complicated tasks in stage2 specifically in the Nav task, for example, I need to specify the go - to target in the nav task?

Is there any further reason why stage 2 didn't have a text input condition?
comments: Finally, someone is asking this! Yes, keeping the text input seems more reasonable. Our final version is primarily an empirical choice. Initially, we kept the text input for the LAM encoder in stage 2 but found that dropping it performs better. You can try both designs in your own setting to see which one works best.

I'm very curious about this issue as well. 
- The 1st stage is called **task-irrelevant** while task instructions are provided. 
- The 2nd stage is called **task-centric** while task information is not given.
What are the reasons behind those terminologies?

Thanks for bringing this up! During the first stage of training, the strong information bottleneck created by the VQ-VAE codebook forces the learned latent actions to capture only the information not inferable from task instructions—resulting in task-irrelevant latent actions.

In the second stage, with these task-irrelevant latents frozen, the newly initialized latent actions are trained to replace the role of language, allowing them to learn task-centric dynamics.

This also explains why, in naive latent action learning approaches like LAPA and Genie, latent action tokens mostly encode motion/dynamics—since texture information is already preserved from previous frames for future frame prediction in the decoder.

If your goal is to learn task-relevant tokens, why not directly use contrastive learning to encode those tokens and perform a soft alignment with the text instruction features? Have you tried this approach? It seems like a more straightforward way to achieve your objective.

@retsuh-bqw Thanks for your detailed explanation.

To support your claims, I think it would be helpful to demonstrate what kind of behavior the latent actions actually exhibit. Have you tried comparing them in a way similar to LAPA Figure 13? Or perhaps visualizing the reconstructions like in LAPA Figure 14?

> If your goal is to learn task-relevant tokens, why not directly use contrastive learning to encode those tokens and perform a soft alignment with the text instruction features? Have you tried this approach? It seems like a more straightforward way to achieve your objective.

@dreamcubeblock We haven't tried this approach yet, but here's our reasoning: During a task episode, the latent action should evolve over time while the language instruction remains the same. Explicit contrastive alignment could harm convergence in this case, as it may be more suitable for learning latent actions that represent the entire task rollout rather than individual steps.

> [@retsuh-bqw](https://github.com/retsuh-bqw) Thanks for your detailed explanation.
> 
> To support your claims, I think it would be helpful to demonstrate what kind of behavior the latent actions actually exhibit. Have you tried comparing them in a way similar to LAPA Figure 13? Or perhaps visualizing the reconstructions like in LAPA Figure 14?

@JisuHann Thank you for your suggestion. While we cannot perform explicit reconstruction (since LAM operates in DINO space rather than raw pixels), we have conducted related analyses:

- Figures 8 & A-1 demonstrate that latent actions exhibit semantic consistency across environments and embodiments.

- Figure A-3 explores the attention patterns between latent actions and DINO features.

repository.description: [RSS 2025] Learning to Act Anywhere with Task-centric Latent Actions
repository.name: UniVLA

summary.main: Why LAM stage 2 didn't use text encoder and what are the reasons behind it.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is labeled as a 'good first issue'.
summary.attemptedFixes: The authors did not try contrastive learning approach, but instead have conducted related analyses to demonstrate the behavior of latent actions.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the LAM stage 2 not using text encoder and the reasons behind it. The authors found that dropping the text input performs better. There are also discussions about task-irrelevant and task-centric stages, and how the latent actions evolve over time.

issueDTO.title: ailure to follow correct numbering
issueDTO.description:
If the titles are in the format [title] 1, [title] 2,..., [title] 10, it will sort [title] 1, [title] 10,..., [title] 2 instead of the correct ordering of 1, 2, 3,..., 10. This happened in left-to-right mode; I haven't tested it in Weebtoon mode.
It happened on a Kobo Clara HD.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c1f8e3d1-14bc-4654-a326-e986ff2e4e84)
comments:
This behavior was removed in

- #920

Sounds like we need to make it an option for cbz. 

It will order properly in epub kepub. Or use koreader. 

You can use 7.4 in meantime. 

I wonder if there's some other set of conditions we can trigger this behavior rather than an option, KCC already has a lot of options...

I would probably just do what I commented earlier, zero pad the numbers.

```python
def slugify(value):
    if options.format != 'CBZ':
        value = slugify_ext(value, regex_pattern=r'[^-a-z0-9_\.]+').strip('.')
    value = sub(r'0*([0-9]{4,})', r'\1', sub(r'([0-9]+)', r'0000\1', value, count=2))
    return value
```

nevermind, lots of people don't want zero padding either in the kcc discord... hmmm.

What if we did it in a way where it only zero pads if it would change the order? That's an idea. @orpheus1120 in case you have insight.

And it would only zero pad minimum amount...
OK, implemented above, please try it out. It will only zero pad and slugify if it would change the sort order, otherwise it leaves it untouched. @lalo101097 @orpheus1120

issueDTO.title: OpenAI Provider Integration
issueDTO.description:
**1. Overview:**

Ensure robust and up-to-date integration of the OpenAI API as a core LLM provider within the `voltagent` framework, utilizing the official `openai` Node.js SDK. This involves verifying support for the latest OpenAI models (GPT-4, GPT-3.5 variants), features (like tool calling, JSON mode), and ensuring the implementation aligns perfectly with the `LLMProvider` interface and `voltagent` conventions.

**2. Goals:**

*   Implement or verify a dedicated `OpenAIProvider` class adhering to the `LLMProvider` interface.
*   Support core generation functionalities (`generateText`, `streamText`, `generateObject`, `streamObject`) using OpenAI models.
*   Utilize the latest official `openai` Node.js SDK.
*   Correctly map `voltagent` generation options (model, temperature, max tokens, tool choice, etc.) to OpenAI API parameters.
*   Implement robust support for OpenAI's tool calling mechanism, mapping seamlessly to `voltagent`'s tool definition and execution flow.
*   Support OpenAI's JSON mode for reliable structured output generation (`generateObject`/`streamObject`).
*   Handle authentication using OpenAI API keys.
*   Integrate OpenAI-specific error handling and response parsing.

**3. Proposed Architecture & Components:**

*   **`OpenAIProvider`:** A class (potentially existing but needing review/update) within `agent/providers` implementing `LLMProvider`. It should:
    *   Use the official `openai` Node.js library.
    *   Handle API client initialization (API key, potentially base URL for proxies).
    *   Implement `generateText`, `streamText`, `generateObject`, `streamObject`, correctly formatting requests (messages, tools, model parameters) and parsing responses/streams.
    *   Specifically handle the `tool_calls` and `tool_results` message flow for tool usage.
*   **Provider Registration:** Ensure `OpenAIProvider` is correctly registered and selectable.
*   **Configuration:** Allow users to select 'openai' as the provider, specify models (e.g., 'gpt-4-turbo', 'gpt-3.5-turbo'), and provide API keys.
*   **Tool Mapping:** Refine the logic that translates `voltagent` tool definitions into the format expected by the OpenAI API's `tools` parameter and processes `tool_calls` responses.

**4. Affected Core Modules:**

*   `agent/providers`: `OpenAIProvider` class implementation/refinement.
*   `agent/types`: Ensure types accurately reflect OpenAI's request/response structures, especially for tools.
*   `ToolManager`: Interaction with `OpenAIProvider` for formatting tool definitions and handling tool calls.
*   `Agent`/`Agent Options`: Configuration for provider selection, models, and credentials.
*   Requires the `openai` dependency.

**5. Acceptance Criteria (Initial MVP / Refinement):**

*   Users can configure an `Agent` to use `OpenAIProvider` with various GPT models (e.g., GPT-4 Turbo, GPT-3.5 Turbo) and an API key.
*   `agent.generateText()` and `agent.streamText()` work correctly.
*   `agent.generateObject()` and `agent.streamObject()` utilize OpenAI's JSON mode successfully.
*   Agents can reliably use tools defined in `voltagent`, with requests and responses correctly handled via the OpenAI tool calling API.
*   Relevant options (temperature, max tokens, tool choice) are passed correctly.
*   Integration uses the current version of the official `openai` SDK.
*   Documentation reflects the updated/verified OpenAI integration details.

**6. Potential Challenges & Considerations:**

*   Keeping up with frequent updates and changes in the OpenAI API and SDK.
*   Ensuring the tool calling implementation is robust and handles various edge cases (multiple tool calls, errors).
*   Mapping `voltagent`'s internal state/history accurately to the sequence of messages expected by OpenAI, especially when including tool results.
*   Handling differences in behavior or features across different OpenAI models.
*   Cost management and monitoring token usage for OpenAI API calls.

issueDTO.title: Add "Rename" Button for Preset Management with Popup Modal
issueDTO.description:
Add "Rename" Button for Preset Management with Popup Modal

**Description:**
We need to add a "Rename" button between the ComboBox (for selecting presets) and the "Delete" button. When clicked, this button should open a popup modal asking the user to enter a new name for the selected preset. Upon confirming, the preset's name should be updated in the object (`presets.name`) and the associated file. The previous file with the old name should be deleted.

**Tasks:**

1. **Add the "Rename" button:**
   - Place the "Rename" button between the ComboBox (preset selector) and the "Delete" button.
   - Ensure the button is clearly labeled and fits within the existing layout.

2. **Implement the popup modal:**
   - Create a modal that appears when the "Rename" button is clicked.
   - The modal should include:
     - An input field for the new preset name.
     - "Confirm" and "Cancel" buttons.
   - The "Confirm" button should only be enabled if the input field is not empty.

3. **Handle renaming logic:**
   - Update the `presets.name` property with the new name when the user clicks "Confirm".
   - Rename the corresponding preset file to match the new name and delete the old file.
   - Ensure the file renaming is done safely, checking for any name conflicts or invalid characters.

4. **Update the ComboBox selection and display:**
   - Refresh the ComboBox options to reflect the updated preset name.
   - Maintain the current selection in the ComboBox with the new name after renaming.

5. **Test the renaming functionality:**
   - Verify that the "Rename" button opens the modal correctly.
   - Test renaming with various inputs (valid, invalid, empty, conflicting names).
   - Confirm that the file is renamed correctly and the old file is deleted.
   - Ensure the ComboBox updates to reflect the new name without issues.

6. **Update documentation:**
   - Document the new "Rename" functionality.
   - Update any relevant sections of the user guide to explain how to rename presets.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- The "Rename" button appears between the ComboBox and "Delete" button and functions as intended.
- The popup modal asks the user for a new name, and the "Confirm" button only works when a valid name is provided.
- The preset's name is updated both in the object (`presets.name`) and the corresponding file.
- The previous file is deleted after renaming.
- The ComboBox correctly displays the updated preset name.
- Documentation is updated to reflect the new feature.

**Additional Context:**
- The project uses ImGui, and the modal should integrate seamlessly with the existing UI.
- Ensure that renaming presets does not interfere with other functionalities like saving, loading, or deleting presets.

issueDTO.title: Request for clearer error message parsing pyproject.toml
issueDTO.description:
### Issue Kind

Change in current behaviour

### Description

When the tool.poetry.source section in pyproject.toml is provided as a `[single table]` rather than `[[array of tables]]` the error poetry provides isn't very helpful:
```
The Poetry configuration is invalid:
  - data.source must be array
```

A more descriptive error and/or a reference to what section or line in the toml would be a little more friendly.  Tried this with -vvv and the stack trace also doesn't give a clue to what part of the toml is actually the problem.

A more broad way to phrase it, if you like,  might be "toml structure errors should report a line or section if possible" 

### Impact

Some more info in the error would make troubleshooting faster; as it is one either 'just knows' the expected structure or goes section by section, which might be slower or faster depending on the size of pyproject.toml.

### Workarounds

None that I'm aware of
comments:
> Landed on this issue after running into this myself.
> 
> [@Evan0000000000](https://github.com/Evan0000000000) , any chance you can post an example / description of solution as you've proposed. Other people may end up here too looking to understand what the error means.
> 
> I am one of those people, new to using poetry and I do not "just know" the solution. Additionally, OpenAI seems to strangely bounce you back-and-forth between two equally obscure error messages if you cut-and-paste the error & ask for assistance.

Hey Jeremy, sure, as an example, in pyproject.toml the `tool.poetry.source` section must be an array, like `[[tool.poetry.source]]` even if you only specify one source. This makes total sense as arrays with 1 entry are completely valid.  

The confusion is that poetry will give you the error in my original message, which tells you something should be an array but not _which_ something, so the solution currently is just to review your pyproject.toml file very carefully with respect to what each tool you have using it expects.

We already replace `data.` with `tool.poetry.` in https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry-core/blob/002aa3e16f98d21645bb9a45f698b55adc40f317/src/poetry/core/factory.py#L606-L609.

We probably have to do the same in https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/blob/aeaa3d09ce7381bf34ac7e0ac27b929841256c90/src/poetry/factory.py#L335.

repository.description: Python packaging and dependency management made easy
repository.name: poetry

summary.main: Request for clearer error message parsing pyproject.toml
summary.validationOrRequirement: The tool.poetry.source section in pyproject.toml must be an array, like [[tool.poetry.source]].
summary.attemptedFixes: The solution is to review the pyproject.toml file carefully and ensure that the tool.poetry.source section is an array, even if it only contains one source.
summary.otherNotes: The error message is unclear, and the stack trace doesn't provide information about the problematic section or line in the toml file. A more descriptive error message and/or a reference to what section or line in the toml file would be helpful.

issueDTO.title: Allow `CapacityLimiter` to have `total_tokens=0`
issueDTO.description:
Sometimes, there are use-cases where you want to entirely pause processing of some tasks, and then later scale back up.  `CapacityLimiter` is basically perfect for this kind of thing, except that it currently raises an error if you pass `total_tokens=0`:

https://github.com/python-trio/trio/blob/d988edd368f094855bd1c36442302113f45f2a1c/src/trio/_sync.py#L254-L255

It's already possible to get the desired effect just by deliberately "leaking" one of the tokens, but it would be much nicer to simply allow zero as the intended capacity, by editing the numbers in the setter above.
comments: Might need to make sure this is tested too, since zero is rather susceptible to edge cases. Looks safe though.
@Zac-HD , I'm interested, could you kindly assign me this task

It's already possible to get the desired effect just by deliberately "leaking" one of the tokens, but it would be much nicer to simply allow zero as the intended capacity, by editing the numbers in the setter above.

# Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue (YAML/Docker)
## Create a Configuration for a Multi-Service Application
*Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!*

## How to get started
Open the `tasks/yaml/medium` directory from the root of your project.
Then open up the `docker-compose.yml` file and once it is properly created according to the YAML syntax and the task in hand, you are done and ready to make a pull request!
*Note: You can test your YAML code in a editor like [this](http://www.yamllint.com/)*.

## Description:

Your task is to create a `docker-compose.yml` file that describes a multi-service application. This application should contain:

-   A web server running on port 8080 using the nginx image.
-   A database server running on the default port using the postgres image.

The web server should have access to the database server but not vice versa.

## Requirements:

-   Use Docker Compose version 3.
-   Specify service names, image versions, and exposed ports.
-   Set up a custom network and make sure only the web server can communicate with the database.
-   Use environment variables to set the database name, user, and password for the PostgreSQL service.

## Example Structure:

```yaml
version: '3'

services:
  # Define your services here
  
networks:
  # Define your networks here
```

## Evaluation Criteria:

-   Valid YAML syntax.
-   Correct use of Docker Compose version and features.
-   Correct network setup.
-   The web server should be able to connect to the database, but the database should not have access to the web server.

---

Check out [README.md](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions and how to make a pull request.

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

issueDTO.description: Imagine, we generated De Bruijn sequence using command `ppd 1024` (1024 bytes) and fed some vulnerable program it as input, then spotted one of the registers has a value that is part of the sequence. Instead of using round about ways ("wx `ppd 1024`; /x 0x414141") we could provide a shortcut for users to do that in the easiest way possible: `<cmd> 0x41414141` that will return the position in the sequence directly.

### Problem or Use Case

We get very common questions re: how to assign and unassign issues, people that do not install the project, and people that make documentation PRs but do not create a rendered preview. It is clear that many contributors are not reading the contributing.MD or the documentation update readme.

# Fork, Commit, Merge - Medium Issue (Bash)

## Create a Bash Script to Monitor Disk Space and Send Email Alert
*Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!*

### Objective:
Create a Bash script that checks the available disk space on your machine. If the available space falls below a certain threshold, the script should send an email alert to a specified email address.

Requirements:
-   Threshold for low disk space should be configurable (e.g., below 20%).
-   The email should contain detailed information about the disk space status.
-   Use the `df` command for getting disk space information.
-   Use `mail` command to send email.

Next step is optional but if you would like to make this actually functional for email sending, you could use for example the mail command-line utility for that:

On Linux/Ubuntu:
```bash
sudo apt-get install mailutils
```

On macOS:
```bash
brew install mailutils
```

### To run the script:

Make sure you are in the correct directory with the command:
```bash
cd tasks/bash/medium
```

Ensure you have the required permissions to execute the script by running this command:

```bash
chmod +x disk_monitor.sh
```

Execute the script:

```bash
./disk_monitor.sh
```

---

To work with this issue, you need to have Bash installed to your local machine.
Check out [README.md](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions of installing Bash and how to make a pull request.

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

# Fork, Commit, Merge - Hard Issue (Python)

## Implementing a Decision Tree Classifier from Scratch
*Note: You don't have ask permission to start solving the issue or get assigned, since these issues are supposed to be always open for new contributors. The actions-user bot will reset the file back to previous state for the next contributor after your commit is merged. So you can just simply start working with the issue right away!*

## How to get started

For this task you need to have Python and NumPy installed. Check out [Installing Python](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge#installing-python) section in README if you need to install Python. If you already have Python installed, you can install NumPy using pip (Python's package installer) with the following terminal command:

```bash
pip install numpy
```

Or, if you're using Python 3 specifically and have both Python 2 and Python 3 installed, you may need to use:

```bash
pip3 install numpy
```

After that you can open the `tasks/python/hard` directory from the root of the project. 
Then open `decision_tree.py` file and start working on your solution!

![python-hard](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/assets/82566656/3fc4a704-a734-4b90-90fc-476ab367b7a1)

## Description

Implement a Decision Tree Classifier from scratch using Python. Do not use libraries like scikit-learn that have pre-implemented classifiers; instead, use basic libraries like NumPy for numerical calculations.

Objectives:

-   Understand the theory behind Decision Trees.
-   Implement a simple yet functional Decision Tree Classifier.
-   Test the classifier on a dataset.

Use any freely available classification dataset. Ensure the dataset has at least 3 features and at least 2 classes.

Implementation Steps:
-   Write functions to calculate Gini impurity or Information Gain.
-   Implement a class DecisionTree with methods for fitting and predicting.
-   Implement a function to print/visualize the tree.

Testing:
-   Split the dataset into training and test sets and evaluate your classifier.

Acceptance Criteria:

-   Successfully implement a Decision Tree Classifier from scratch.
-   Evaluate the classifier on a dataset, showing reasonable performance metrics (e.g., accuracy, precision, recall).

Resources:

-   [Decision Trees - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree_learning)

## How to run

Make sure you are in the right directory:

```bash
cd tasks/python/hard
```

Execute the following command to run your Python script:

```bash
python decision_tree.py
```

## Expected output

Output should look similar to this:

```bash
The predicted class for the sample [0.4, 0.6] is 0.
```

If the output looks correct, you are ready to make a pull request!

---

To work with this issue, you need to have Python installed to your local machine.
Check out [README.md](https://github.com/nikohoffren/fork-commit-merge/blob/main/README.md) for more instructions of installing Python and how to make a pull request.

Feel free to ask any questions here if you have some problems!

issueDTO.title: Drill to Detail is not working properly on Charts powered by Jinja Templating
issueDTO.description:
### Bug description

## Description
Dashboard charts that are powered by Jinja are able to display their data correctly. However, when users try to perform the drill-by action, the result is incorrect.

## How to reproduce the bug
1. By following [**this guide**](https://preset.io/blog/intro-jinja-templating-apache-superset/#using-jinja-to-filter-data-walkthrough), create a Jinja-powered dataset with `country`, `status`, and `product_line` columns.
2. Create a stacked Bar Chart and add it to a dashboard.
3. Add a filter for the Product Line from the `Vehicle Sales` dataset.
4. Ensure that the dashboard shows correct data.
5. On the stacked Bar Chart, perform a **drill to detail by all** action.

## Expected results
Drill-by results are correct.

## Actual results
Drill-by results are incorrect.

## Known Workarounds
No workarounds are currently known.


### Screenshots/recordings

_No response_

### Superset version

master / latest-dev

### Python version

3.9

### Node version

16

### Browser

Chrome

### Additional context

_No response_

### Checklist

- [x] I have searched Superset docs and Slack and didn't find a solution to my problem.
- [x] I have searched the GitHub issue tracker and didn't find a similar bug report.
- [ ] I have checked Superset's logs for errors and if I found a relevant Python stacktrace, I included it here as text in the "additional context" section.
comments:
<!-- Answer -->
This issue is caused by a disconnect between the context available to Jinja templates during regular chart rendering and what is provided during drill-to-detail actions. When you drill, the frontend sends a new request that often lacks the full dashboard/global context (like dashboard filters or URL params) that your Jinja SQL expects, so the template renders incorrectly or with missing values. This is a known limitation and has been discussed in several issues and code reviews ([example](https://github.com/apache/superset/issues/33591), [example](https://github.com/apache/superset/issues/33579)).

A workaround is to make your Jinja SQL more robust by using `if/else` blocks to provide default values when filters are missing, so the query always returns results and columns don't disappear. For example:

```sql
WITH calculation as (
  SELECT count(*), country
  FROM "Vehicle Sales"
  WHERE 1=1
  {% if filter_values('product_line') %}
    and product_line in {{ filter_values('product_line')|where_in }}
  {% else %}
    and product_line = 'Classic Cars'
  {% endif %}
  GROUP BY country
)
SELECT * FROM calculation
```
([source](https://github.com/apache/superset/issues/33591))

If your dataset relies on dashboard-level filters or variables, you may need to adjust your Jinja logic to handle cases where those are missing during drill actions.

There have also been recent changes to how Superset syncs dataset columns and processes Jinja templates, which can impact this behavior ([PR 30903](https://github.com/apache/superset/pull/30903)). Make sure your configuration enables `ENABLE_TEMPLATE_PROCESSING` and that your feature flags are up to date.

At this time, there is no full workaround for preserving all dashboard context in drill-to-detail requests, but making your Jinja SQL more defensive can help avoid empty or broken results.


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->
*To reply, just mention [@dosu](https://go.dosu.dev/dosubot).*

issueDTO.title: [BUG] The Backup YAML example in the Longhorn doc does not work
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the Bug

The Backup YAML example in [our doc website](https://longhorn.io/docs/1.9.0/snapshots-and-backups/backup-and-restore/create-a-backup) does not work. Because Longhorn mutator webhook requires providing [the correct `metadata.labels`](https://github.com/longhorn/longhorn-manager/blob/16f796214eb359cdb9f9efbe577a2de68144081b/webhook/resources/backup/mutator.go#L63-L67) while the doc does not mention that.

There are 2 solutions for this:
- Simply updating the doc by adding `metadata.labels` for the example YAMLs
- The mutator should figure out and set up the labels automatically based on the input `spec.snapshotName`

Now I may prefer the latter one since this solution can both
- provide a better user experience
- and forcibly ask the mutator to check the volume and snapshot existence before backup creation

### To Reproduce

1. Create and attach a volume
2. Create a random snapshot
3. Apply the following backup YAML provided by the doc:
```
apiVersion: longhorn.io/v1beta2
kind: Backup
metadata:
  name: backup-example
  namespace: longhorn-system
spec:
  backupMode: full
  snapshotName: <volume snapshot name>
  labels:
    app: test
```

### Expected Behavior

The backup should be created correctly

### Support Bundle for Troubleshooting

```
ubuntu:~$ kubectl apply -f backup.yaml
Error from server (InternalError): error when creating "backup.yaml": Internal error occurred: failed calling webhook "mutator.longhorn.io": failed to call webhook: post "https://longhorn-admission-webhock.longhorn-system.svc:9502/v1/webhook/mutation?timeout=10s": EOF
```

### Environment

- Longhorn version: master-head (07/02/2025)

### Additional context

This issue was found by community contributor @nzhan126  when she tried to test a backup-related fix. 

### Workaround and Mitigation

Set up `matadata.labels` for the backup YAML. For example:
```
apiVersion: longhorn.io/v1beta2
kind: Backup
metadata:
  name: backup-example
  namespace: longhorn-system
  labels:
    backup-volume: <volume name>
spec:
  backupMode: full
  snapshotName: <volume snapshot name>
  labels:
    app: test
```

issueDTO.title: No sound on desktop notifications anymore ?
issueDTO.description:
I'm currently working with Tauri v2, and I'm trying to send notifications with sound on desktop platforms (macOS, Windows, etc.).

From the [v1 documentation](https://v1.tauri.app/v1/api/js/notification/#sound), it's clear that we could set a sound option for notifications:

> The sound file to play when the notification is shown.


However, in the [v2 documentation](https://v2.tauri.app/reference/javascript/notification/#options), the sound option is explicitly noted as:

> The sound resource name. Only available on mobile.


It seems that this functionality was either removed or not yet implemented for desktop in v2.


- Is there a plan to bring back desktop notification sounds support in v2?
- If not, could it be considered for a future release?

Thanks for the amazing work on Tauri!
comments: Oh damn. In alpha times we planned to bring this back before stable but completely lost track of it. This should be relatively easy to bring back since notify-rust has sound support and it should look quite similar to the v1 impl so probably a straight forward port.
Waiting for the PR to be merged, however got the sound working by adding a custom sound playback on when notification is sent!

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Support for PP-OCRv5's New Model Format (inference.json, inference.pdiparams, inference.yml)
issueDTO.description:
### Request Description

PaddleOCR recently updated the model format for PP-OCRv5 . The previous format used three files:

> inference.pdmodel
> 
> inference.pdiparams
> 
> inference.pdiparams.info

The new format now consists of:

> inference.json
> 
> inference.pdiparams
> 
> inference.yml

This change breaks compatibility with OpenVINO’s current PaddlePaddle model support, which expects the legacy file structure.
Could the OpenVINO team confirm if there are plans to:
Add support for the new PP-OCRv5 model format?
PP-OCRv5 is a state-of-the-art OCR model widely adopted in production deployments.
Users upgrading to PP-OCRv5 will be blocked from leveraging OpenVINO’s optimizations without format compatibility.

### Feature Use Case

_No response_

### Issue submission checklist

- [x] The feature request or improvement must be related to OpenVINO

issueDTO.title: [Feature] add a page about using the H2 database
issueDTO.description:
### Feature Request

There is a page about MySQL.
https://hertzbeat.apache.org/docs/help/mysql/

From the mailing lists, there is evidence that some users are using Hertzbeat with H2 databases.

H2 Database is not meant to be used in production environments and has dangerous functionality that allows users to run scripts that can run raw Java commands - including very dangerous Java commands.

I would suggest that you read https://h2database.com/html/security.html - the really worrying bit is the 'CREATE ALIAS' bit. With CREATE ALIAS support, you let malicious users get full access to the Hertzbeat server and run shell commands.

Can we add a page that tells users that H2 support in Hertzbeat is meant for testing in sandboxed environment and it isn't meant for production?

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

_No response_

### Describe the solution you'd like

_No response_

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

Ray is a popular AI framework that has been widely used, and ray operator has already supported Volcano as a batch scheduler, see：https://github.com/ray-project/kuberay
On the other hand, many users still use volcano job to run their job instead of new ray API，so it's reasonable to support ray natively on volcano job.

Currently volcano supports distributed AI and HPC framework like pytorch, tensorflow,  mpi.
Just like what vcjobs currently do, and a new plugin named `ray` in pkg/controllers/job/plugins/distributed-framework, so users can submit a vcjob and actually run a ray job.

issueDTO.title: Automate manual post-installation steps for Docker setup
issueDTO.description:
## Issue Description

Currently, the Docker installation process requires several manual steps to be executed after running `docker-compose up --build -d`. These manual steps create friction for new users and go against Docker's principle of providing a complete, automated setup experience.

## Current Manual Steps

After running `docker-compose up --build -d`, users must manually execute:

```bash
docker exec -it samarium_app npm run dev
docker exec -it samarium_app composer dump-autoload
docker exec -it samarium_app php artisan migrate
docker exec -it samarium_app php artisan key:generate
docker exec -it samarium_app php artisan storage:link
docker exec -it samarium_app php artisan db:seed
```

## Expected Behavior

The Docker setup should be fully automated - users should only need to run:
1. `cp .env.docker.example .env`
2. `docker-compose up --build -d`

After these commands, the application should be ready to use without any additional manual intervention.

issueDTO.title: Introduce a meta scan function for inspecting table column size
issueDTO.description:
<!-- (At least include the following, feel free to add if you have more content) -->

## Feature request

StarRocks support several functions to inspect the metadata of segment files:
```sql
select count(id) from t1 [_META_];
select min(id) from t1 [_META_];
select max(id) from t1 [_META_];
select flat_json_meta(payload) from t1 [_META_];
```

Essentially it generates a `META_SCAN` operator to scan the metadata of underlying segment files, then aggregate the result with `count/min/max` functions.

We can leverage this mechanism to inspect the column size of a table, for example:

```sql
select column_size(id) from t1 [_META_];
```

There are several types of column sizes:  
- **Uncompressed Size**: Stored in the `ColumnMetaPB` located in the segment footer.  
- **Compressed Size**: Represents the on-disk size. While it is not explicitly stored in the footer, it can be estimated by analyzing the number of pages via the `OrdinalIndex` and calculating the average page size.  

It might be worthwhile to include a few functions for inspecting a column's metadata.

Further more, we can also consider add these column stats into the optimizer statistics system, stored in the `_statistics_.column_statistics` table.

issueDTO.description: it would be great if there would be some documentation about `MediaMetadata::cover_url`, like what format it should be in, or if there is anything platform specific (and if needed what formats are supported, like recommending jpg?)
comments:
It is very platform specific. As of now, Souvlaki leaves it up to the user to change the URL depending on the platform.

For Linux, we follow the MPRIS specification, which actually doesn't say much cover art apart from what's in [here](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/mpris-spec/metadata/#mpris:arturl). It only says that local files should start with `file://` and that it should be an UTF-8 string, which is enforced by Rust. Maybe you can look in the source code of desktop managers such as GNOME or KDE, since these read the field to display it on their media player controls.

For Windows, we use the _SystemMediaTransportControlsDisplayUpdater_, which has [a thumbnail property](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.media.systemmediatransportcontrolsdisplayupdater.thumbnail?view=winrt-22621#windows-media-systemmediatransportcontrolsdisplayupdater-thumbnail). It accepts multiple formats, but we choose to create it using an URI. If setting an URL starting with `file://`, the file is automatically loaded by souvlaki.

For MacOS, you can look into [these lines](https://github.com/Sinono3/souvlaki/blob/384539fe83e8bf5c966192ba28e9405e3253619b/src/platform/macos/mod.rs#L131-L137) of the implementation. These lines refer to creating an [MPMediaItemArtwork](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/mediaplayer/mpmediaitemartwork) object.

I hope this is of use to you. If you find a good way to put this information in the docs, consider opening a pull request 🙂
Documented in 5b89e4bae455e5aed07e2f57f9d8a5b92e62ecf5

As a FYI and because not much is documented in the respective platforms and at least verified on Linux-MPRIS-dbus-KDE, the format of `data:MIMETYPE;base64,BASE64DATA` seems to work without problems.
And i have not yet seen complaints of it not working in windows, mac or other linux environments.
By the way, [mpv-mpris](https://archlinux.org/packages/extra/x86_64/mpv-mpris/) seems to also use this format on linux.

[termusic souvlaki cover_art setting](https://github.com/tramhao/termusic/blob/4fa58b87f15f5d87f705de2b38998563d28ba480/playback/src/mpris.rs#L73-L91).
[MDN data: URLs - URIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/URI/Reference/Schemes/data)

> As a FYI and because not much is documented in the respective platforms and at least verified on Linux-MPRIS-dbus-KDE, the format of `data:MIMETYPE;base64,BASE64DATA` seems to work without problems. And i have not yet seen complaints of it not working in windows, mac or other linux environments. By the way, mpv seems to also use this format on linux.
> 
> [termusic souvlaki cover_art setting](https://github.com/tramhao/termusic/blob/4fa58b87f15f5d87f705de2b38998563d28ba480/playback/src/mpris.rs#L73-L91). [MDN data: URLs - URIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/URI/Reference/Schemes/data)

Perhaps this is the solution to https://github.com/Sinono3/souvlaki/issues/62 for Linux? That's pretty neat, I've noticed even Google Chrome writes to a temporary file and uses a a `file://` url when using MPRIS.

Wow @hasezoey, that's actually great news. I'll add that to the docs as well, but before I'll test on macOS and Windows.

- [x] Data URLs working on macOS
- [ ] Data URLs working on Windows

Working well on Windows!

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/807892b0-b10d-4f12-8d2d-b3933dc80f9f)

One thing to note - seems like you **must** call `set_cover` before `set_metadata`. I made the mistake of calling them in the wrong order and the cover art would only be updated on the next time the track changed

> Working well on Windows!

Just to confirm, are you referring to the data urls (`data:`) i mentioned earlier?

> Just to confirm, are you referring to the data urls (`data:`) i mentioned earlier?

there's a native Windows API for loading images as bytes (which is what works) but it does fall back to data URLs on MPRIS

summary.main: Add documentation on how `cover_url` is meant to be used, including the recommended format and any platform-specific requirements.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The `cover_url` should be in the format of `data:MIMETYPE;base64,BASE64DATA`. It's recommended to use this format.

issueDTO.title: 2025 Spring AI Alibaba 技术博客/视频征集
issueDTO.description:
### Description

如果您在调研或者使用Spring AI Alibaba和Jmanus，欢迎<font style="color:rgb(31, 35, 40);">大家用自己擅长的方式创作Spring AI Alibaba/Jmanus相关作品，并通过技术博客或者短视频分享Spring AI Alibaba/Jmanus的介绍、技术解析、最佳实践、使用案例。</font>

## 参与方式:
1.撰写技术博客或者制作视频，发布至个人博客、CSDN等开发者社区、B站、视频号等视频平台；
2.将**本月发布**的文章/视频地址发布至此 issue 评论区；（例子：如果您参与的是7月的活动，只有7月发布的文章、视频才是有效投稿，历史文章无效）
3.投稿后通过这个地址[提交个人收件信息](https://survey.aliyun.com/apps/zhiliao/aX4Z_BS8a)


## 奖品说明
1. 社区参与奖（数量不限）：只要投稿的作者就可以获得阿里巴巴开源纪念品，咖啡杯、T恤二选一
2. 优秀贡献奖（2名）：每月最后一个工作日，评委会根据投稿内容的技术先进性、内容可读性、文章/视频阅读量三个维度进行打分，评选出2位优秀贡献奖，奖品是无线手机充电支架。


## <font style="color:rgb(31, 35, 40);">投稿作品要求</font>
+ <font style="color:rgb(31, 35, 40);">作品层次结构及逻辑清晰且必须是原创；</font>
+ <font style="color:rgb(31, 35, 40);">禁止发布广告类内容信息；</font>
+ <font style="color:rgb(31, 35, 40);">禁止发布涉政、暴恐、违禁等敏感内容。</font>

issueDTO.title: API: Ability to create secrets and variables in bulk
issueDTO.description:
## Description

The import functionality in the CLI and platform currently calls the API over and over again. This takes up a lot of bandwidth. Having an endpoint that supports bulk upload would fix this issue.

## Solution

We would like to have the following endpoints:
```http
POST /api/secret/:projectSlug/bulk
POST /api/variable/:projectSlug/bulk
```

The implementations would be in the `secret` and `variable` modules. 

The request body would be the same as `createSecret` and `createVariable`, just that it would accept array types. 

Reuse the functionality present for creating a secret and variable

Assigned the issue to @AnantaPodder!

issueDTO.title: Add `User-Agent` header to all API requests
issueDTO.description:
**Description**:

Cartography currently makes HTTP requests without setting a `User-Agent` header. For better observability and integration with vendor APIs, all outbound requests from intel modules should include a standardized `User-Agent`.

**Proposed format**:

```
User-Agent: Cartography/0.x.y
```

Where `0.x.y` corresponds to the current version from `cartography.__version__`. If unavailable (e.g., in development), default to `Cartography/dev`.

**Benefits**:

* Easier debugging and tracing of requests in API logs
* Improves compatibility with vendors that expect or validate user-agents
* Aligns with standard HTTP client practices

**Suggested implementation**:

* Introduce a small utility (e.g., `build_session()`) in `cartography.util` to initialize a `requests.Session` with the appropriate `User-Agent`
* Refactor existing intel modules to use this session instead of directly instantiating `requests.Session()`
comments: Hi, I’d like to take this up.
@akhilvaitlaa7 feel free to work on it :)
My name is [xingaonai](https://www.xgncrusher.com/). The article you wrote is very interesting and taught me a lot. Thank you!

Extend the `/health` endpoint to include instances. Add a function in `lib/runtime` to list them in etcd - see `component.rs` `list_instances` for an example (that one only lists the instances of a Component).

- **@Mention Received** - Fires when someone mentions your bot

- Build chat-based workflows and automations
- Create notification systems

https://developers.google.com/workspace/chat/api/reference/rest/v1/EventType

issueDTO.title: nav2_ros_common interfaces for Services, Subscription, and Action to be lifecycle enabled
issueDTO.description:
Following in the footsteps of the lifecycle publisher, enable the subscription, action server, action client, service server, and service client to have an activate and deactivate method for lifecycle enablement.

These should be added as managed entities and update the Nav2 Task Servers to call a new method `nav2::LifecycleNode::activateInterfaces()` and complimentary in deactivation so that these are all automatically activated and deactivated behind the scenes. Update the task servers to remove the manual activation and deactivation. We do need to take some care that the instantiation of the interfaces then are ordered since some subscription callbacks might depend on some publishers activation or existence. So we should be creating all exporters (i.e. action clients, service clients, publishers) before  consumers (i.e. actions, services, subscribers) -- and deactivating all consumers before exporters (inverted). 

On top, in the nav2 lifecycle node, we should autoactivate if the node is already activated when an interface is created (see `nav2::Publisher` for example)
comments: Hey @SteveMacenski I'd like to work on this

Awesome! I think it makes sense to start off small and do this bit by bit. How about you come up with a game plan and we have some incremental PRs to do this one at a time (subscribers, actions, services, clients, action clients)! Somewhere in there (perhaps after the first?) we should incorporate the boilerplate I mentioned with `activateInterfaces` so that later changes aren't as involved

issueDTO.title: [Variant] Tests for creating "large" `VariantObjects`s
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem or challenge? Please describe what you are trying to do.**
- part of https://github.com/apache/arrow-rs/issues/6736

The [Variant](https://github.com/apache/parquet-format/blob/master/VariantEncoding.md#encoding-types) encoding uses different sizes for offsets in nested types to optimize the encoding size

Specifically
* Objects [use between 1-4 bytes for the field id depending on the number of fields](https://github.com/apache/parquet-format/blob/master/VariantEncoding.md#value-header-for-object-basic_type2)
* Objects [use between 1-4 bytes for the field offset depending on the size of the children](https://github.com/apache/parquet-format/blob/master/VariantEncoding.md#value-header-for-object-basic_type2)


**Describe the solution you'd like**

I would like tests that use the `VariantBuilder` API and cover the following cases:
1. `VariantObject` with between 2^8 and 2^16 elements ( `field_id_size_minus_1` = 1, 2 byte field ids)
2. `VariantObject` with between 2^16 and 2^24 elements ( `field_id_size_minus_1` = 2, 3 byte field ids)
3. `VariantObject` with between 2^24 and 2^32 elements ( `field_id_size_minus_1` = 3, 4 byte field ids)

1. `VariantObject` with total child data length between 2^8 and 2^16 elements ( `field_offset_size_minus_1` = 1, 2 byte field offsets)
2. `VariantObject` with total child data length between 2^16 and 2^24 elements ( `field_offset_size_minus_1` = 2, 3 byte field offsets)
3. `VariantObject` with total child data length between 2^24 and 2^32 elements ( `field_offset_size_minus_1` = 3, 4 byte field offsets)

The "total child data length" can be made by adding some large strings as children (for example, by adding 1KB - 1MB `Varaint::String`s via `ArrayBuilder::append`)


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
<!--
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.
-->

**Additional context**
The tests may not pass until this ticket is implemented:
- https://github.com/apache/arrow-rs/issues/7699

If they dont' pass, we can mark them `#[ignored]` until it is
comments: take

repository.description: Official Rust implementation of Apache Arrow
repository.name: arrow-rs

summary.validationOrRequirement: use between 1-4 bytes for the field id depending on the number of fields, use between 1-4 bytes for the field offset depending on the size of the children
summary.attemptedFixes: tests that use the `VariantBuilder` API

issueDTO.title: Build correct SQLAlchemy URI in hooks based on `DbApiHook`
issueDTO.description:
### Body

Original discussion: https://lists.apache.org/thread/8rhmz3qh30hvkondct4sfmgk4vd07mn5

tl;dr; `DbApiHook` assumes that Airflow Connection URI representation is a valid SA URI, but it is not true and never was, it might work in simple cases, however it will fail in some complex one.

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/2ab60812a040cb8b760acaf396f625d0d719e4be/airflow/providers/common/sql/hooks/sql.py#L184-L192

This task intend to track fixes into the hooks which based on `DbApiHook`.

Hooks which don't overwrite invalid `DbApiHook.get_uri` implementation
---

- [ ] `MySqlHook` from `mysql` provider. This hook provide support for two different drivers.
   + [ ] `mysqlclient`: https://pypi.org/project/mysqlclient/
   + [ ] `mysql-connector-python`: https://pypi.org/project/mysql-connector-python/
- [ ] OracleHook from `oracle` provider
- [ ] JdbcHook from `jdbc` provider
- [ ] TrinoHook from `trino` provider
- [ ] HiveServer2Hook from `apache.hive` provider
- [ ] ImpalaHook from `apache.impala` provider
- [ ] DatabricksSqlHook from `databricks` provider
- [ ] ExasolHook from `exasol` provider
- [ ] PrestoHook from `presto` provider
- [ ] VerticaHook from `vertica` provider
- [ ] TeradataHook from `teradata` provider

Hooks which uses `Connection.get_uri` for construct SQLAlchemy URI
---

- [ ] PostgresHook from `postgres` provider. https://github.com/apache/airflow/issues/38187, https://github.com/apache/airflow/issues/34456
- [ ] MsSqlHook from `microsoft.mssql` provider
- [ ] SqliteHook from `sqlite` provider



### Committer

- [X] I acknowledge that I am a maintainer/committer of the Apache Airflow project.
comments:
hello @Taragolis I was checking this issue and seeing if I could fix it.

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/0e8f108313d4af0b450581661aeb8ed35e82a8e6/airflow/models/connection.py#L271-L329

Is fixing the get_uri part so that  Airflow Connection URI representation becomes a valid SA URI the right way to fix this issue?

As far as i remember, we recently discuss this case in slack. I guess better introduce `sa_uri` property (or some similar naming) which returns [`sqlalchemy.engine.URL`](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/engines.html#sqlalchemy.engine.URL)  into the `DbApiHook` without any implementation, e.g. raise `NotImplementedError` and implements it per hook which have implementation for SQAlchemy. 

`get_uri` - not clear which URI it is implements, DBApi? SQLAlchemy or even some internal ([ElasticsearchSQLHook](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/dec2662190dd4480d0c631da733e19d2ec9a479d/airflow/providers/elasticsearch/hooks/elasticsearch.py#L113))

cc: @potiuk @dstandish

@Taragolis , I am working on this PR - https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/38871 . This is a separate PR to just update the `DbApiHook` to include a method to return a SqlAlchemy URL that can be reused.

> As far as i remember, we recently discuss this case in slack. I guess better introduce `sa_uri` property (or some similar naming) which returns [`sqlalchemy.engine.URL`](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/engines.html#sqlalchemy.engine.URL) into the `DbApiHook` without any implementation, e.g. raise `NotImplementedError` and implements it per hook which have implementation for SQAlchemy.
> 
> `get_uri` - not clear which URI it is implements, DBApi? SQLAlchemy or even some internal ([ElasticsearchSQLHook](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/dec2662190dd4480d0c631da733e19d2ec9a479d/airflow/providers/elasticsearch/hooks/elasticsearch.py#L113))
> 
> cc: @potiuk @dstandish

@Taragolis Why not implement another method named get_url and use that one to instantiate the SQLALchemy engine, as the engine can accept an SQLAlchemy URL object.  Also the SQLAlchemy URL class has a factory method named create, which easily allows you to create the URL without the hastle of string manipulations, this is how I did it for my custom SQL operator (the one I mentioned on Slack):

```
    def get_url(self) -> URL:
        return URL.create(
            self.scheme,
            username=self.connection.login,
            password=self.connection.password,
            host=self.connection.host,
            port=self.connection.port,
        )
```

Also see [here ](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html#creating-urls-programmatically)the SQL documentation concerning creating URL's programmatically: [https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html#creating-urls-programmatically](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html#creating-urls-programmatically)

I see @rawwar was first mentioning this, I think this would be a good idea and would simplify code and be less bug prone.

There is new property which intends to returns SQL Alchemy URL, current behaviour of `get_url` is ambiguous and non-all hook return SA URI here, for some of the DB there is no even SA dialects exists, so better keep `get_url` as is and step-by-step migrate to appropriate ones. So if dialect exists and it installed with provider I do not have any objections to add it implementation as `sqlalchemy_url`

> There is new property which intends to returns SQL Alchemy URL, current behaviour of `get_url` is ambiguous and non-all hook return SA URI here, for some of the DB there is no even SA dialects exists, so better keep `get_url` as is and step-by-step migrate to appropriate ones. So if dialect exists and it installed with provider I do not have any objections to add it implementation as `sqlalchemy_url`

Hey Andrey think there is some confusion here.  Yes we should definitly leave the get_uri method as it is (not get_url as it doesn’t exist yet) and implement a new get_url method which would then be called by the existing get_sqlalchemy_engine.

> Hey Andrey think there is some confusion here. Yes we should definitly leave the get_uri method as it is (not get_url as it doesn’t exist yet) and implement a new get_url method which would then be called by the existing get_sqlalchemy_engine.

Yes, adding new method is the way to go. How to do it, should be proposed and discussed in the PR, we have 20+ sql providers, and I think the proposal should be complete and explain how to deal with cases that can/cannot be mapped. Also the method should explicily - IMHO - call our sqlalachemy, (`getSqlAlchemyURI` ?) and likely allow variations - from what I understand SQLAlchemy can have different URLs not only for different databases, but also for different drivers. Also some of our Connections allows to add different kinds of extras and parameters - not only hosts but other parameters that might be used and passed differently to different drivers.

If we decide to introduce a new "standard" method, in a product like Airflow and common API like DBApiHook, the proposal should provide answers to all the questions that users might ask in order to be mergable. It does not have to handle all of those but at least get enough error handlling and interface specification to explain what is the transition from the Connection form (in all those cases we have DBAPI implementation) -> SQLAlchemy URL.  Which variations are handled, how it should work, how to map engine args etc. 

I don't think it can be handled by a single implementation, it's more a scaffloiding + implementation for all the implementations and it should be designed nicely with al least a handful (if not all) implementation from the above list to be quite sure that we will be able to handle those cases.

> Hey Andrey think there is some confusion here. Yes we should definitly leave the get_uri method as it is (not get_url as it doesn’t exist yet) and implement a new get_url method which would then be called by the existing get_sqlalchemy_engine.

@dabla , I think, we are indeed adding `get_url` functionality using `sqlalchemy_url` property.

Hi, I think I could help with this issue~ 
Also, I have submitted some PR toward this issues
@guan404ming what are the open items left on this issue? I see you handled several of them
I plan to get back here after `get_df` migration and I think I would handle the remaining later.

this PR [Fix overwrite get_uri for Oracle #48734](https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/48734) dont work for get_sqlalchemy_conn because oracledb is supported on SqlAlchemy major 2, which cause error `sqlalchemy.exc.NoSuchModuleError: Can't load plugin: sqlalchemy.dialects:oracle.oracledb`.

Force "+oracledb" in line 465 broke the code
`uri = f"oracle+oracledb://{login}:{password}@{host}:{port}"`

Also, [test_oracle.py](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/providers-oracle/4.1.0/providers/oracle/tests/unit/oracle/hooks/test_oracle.py) file dont check get_sqlalchemy_conn method.
Hello, I would like to work on this issue.

issueDTO.title: Number of children served -- should not include archived children.
issueDTO.description:
# Summary
Don't count archived children in Total Number of Children served (on bank's view of partner)
# Why?
If a child has been archived, they are no longer being served
# Details
## Where the Total Number of Children referred to above appears
Sign in as org_admin1@example.com
Click Partner Agencies, then "All Partners"
Click on "Pawnee Parent Service"  (this is the partner used below).  This shows the bank's  view of that paratner
The number of children served is shown in the second section.
## Where to archive a child
Sign in as verified@example.com
Click on Children in the left hand menu
Choose a child and "Edit Child Details"
Near the bottom, there is an "Archived?" checkbox.   
Toggle it to checked, and click "Update Child"
## What we need
The number of children in the bank's partner view reflects only the non-archived children for the partner.  Changes to a child's archived status will be reflected in this value.
# Criteria for completion
- [ ] Behaviour as described above
- [ ] automated tests that confirm the behaviour

issueDTO.title: [REQUEST] Process command prefix/regex filtering
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
On NixOS, process commands are always very long because everything is located in the Nix store under a cryptographically-hashed prefix (see screenshot). Even at a very high resolution (3840x1600 in my case) with btop maximized, and the left panel hidden, it's impossible to see the full command much of the time.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like to be able to specify a prefix (maybe regex) to exclude some parts of the process command. For example, instead of `/nix/store/<long string>/bin/.firefox-wrapped --name firefox`, I could configure it to just show `bin/firefox-wrapped --name firefox`.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Using a different distro would solve this but I don't wanna.

**Additional context**
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c08d3137-e71b-492c-b81c-1c86827c9803)
comments:
i was checking here searching if this is reported yet there was a talk about it on https://www.reddit.com/r/NixOS/comments/14jlp5o/viewing_process_info_on_nixos_and_dealing_with/
About 2 years ago that said the following:
- Plasma's "System Monitor" program just shows the executable name, not the whole path (unless you add a column for the path).

issueDTO.title: feat: work as a drop-in ls replacement
issueDTO.description:
Currently, `exa` doesn't support the `-t` flag in the same way as `ls`, so it won't work as a drop in replacement. That is, `ls -ltra` works, but `exa -ltra` won't work.

An issue existed at the exa repository for this: https://github.com/ogham/exa/issues/519

I also wrote a patch fixing this: https://github.com/ogham/exa/commit/fa76a335fd40d1f81b656b3d602309e7d39bed2f

I tried cherry-picking this, but some conflicts seem non-trivial. I'd appreciate hearing some feedback on the patch first, and if it looks good, I'll like to incorporate it into eza. Notably:

- When `-t` is specified with arguments, it behaves much like `exa -t X`.
- When `-t` is specified without arguments, it behaves like `ls`.
comments: this can either be picked up by someone as I myself will wait/implement this in #640 but not in main branch

> * When `-t` is specified with arguments, it behaves much like `exa -t X`.
> 
> * When `-t` is specified without arguments, it behaves like `ls`.

I don't think this can be done. This is because when parsing a single character argument, it is necessary to know if the corresponding argument requires an additional parameter.

According to the existing parsing logic, a command line like `eza -tmodified` is valid. If, as suggested by @WhyNotHugo, `eza` can't tell whether the `ra` after the letter `t` in `eza -ltra` is another two arguments or the parameters belonging to `t`. This is ambiguity.

Quite true. I guess the only options are to chose one of the following:

- Remain compatible with exa.
- Remain compatible with ls.

> I don't think this can be done. This is because when parsing a single character argument, it is necessary to know if the corresponding argument requires an additional parameter.

This is doable, and we have what needed but as Clap is incoming I dont wanna take time to modify it, you are free to do it yourself tho.

I've also discovered recently `ls -p` which suffixes folders with a `/`, making them more distinct, and that eza lacks:
```
➜ eza -p                    
eza: Unknown argument -p
home on  boot-fixes via ❄️  IMPURE (dotfiles-shell-env) 
❌3 ❯ eza --version  
eza - A modern, maintained replacement for ls
v0.18.0 [+git]
https://github.com/eza-community/eza
```

> I've also discovered recently `ls -p` which suffixes folders with a `/`, making them more distinct, and that eza lacks:
> 
> ```
> ➜ eza -p                    
> eza: Unknown argument -p
> home on  boot-fixes via ❄️  IMPURE (dotfiles-shell-env) 
> ❌3 ❯ eza --version  
> eza - A modern, maintained replacement for ls
> v0.18.0 [+git]
> https://github.com/eza-community/eza
> ```

This should probably be a separate issue, seems useful, and easy to implement, although I'm not much for using a single letter flag for this

> I've also discovered recently ls -p which suffixes folders with a /, making them more distinct, and that eza lacks:

`eza -F` works the same as it classifies which type of file it is, it then adds the `/` for directories and `*` for executables and '@' for links

>eza -F works the same

...it works the same unless you try something like `-Fl`.

The `-t` flag is my personal dealbreaking itch with this tool (I run `ls -lrt` ~~hundreds~~ zillions of times per day). I don't want to develop muscle memory for `-lsnew` and find myself fighting with vanilla linux.

I haven't looked at the argument parsing code—is this kind of disambiguation for `ls` compatibility likely to be complicated to implement? I think we all have our repetitive behaviors with `ls`. If this kind of fix is unlikely to work with eza, I might go back to my ancient-but-functional color ls drop-in replacement.

> I haven't looked at the argument parsing code—is this kind of disambiguation for ls compatibility likely to be complicated to implement?

I implemented it and it works on many cases, but there are edge cases where it can be ambiguous ([as mentioned in a comment above](https://github.com/eza-community/eza/issues/736#issuecomment-1922736980)).

> The `-t` flag is my personal dealbreaking itch with this tool (I run `ls -lrt` ~hundreds~ zillions of times per day). I don't want to develop muscle memory for `-lsnew` and find myself fighting with vanilla linux.

@adrian-the-git Yes. It itches me too. So I made a script to wrap eza: when `-lrt` appears the script simply replaces it with `-lsnew`, then sends the argument to eza.

Even if it's not `-t`, is there a possibility of adding some other short option for sorting by mtime? Like others have mentioned I used this *constantly* and I suppose I can add a new shell alias `lst` or `lat` but I would really love to see eza just stick closer to `ls` behavior here.

This is also a dealbreaker for me. I run `ls -lart` too often at too many systems where I just have ls instead of eza. 

Idea: compability env variable for those options? EZA_LS_COMPABILITY=1 ?

> This is also a dealbreaker for me. I run `ls -lart` too often at too many systems where I just have ls instead of eza.
> 
> Idea: compability env variable for those options? EZA_LS_COMPABILITY=1 ?

Our plan is to introduce a flag that makes eza ls compatible, this is gonna be done after the clap migration

A lot of specific feedback seems to get lost in this thread, if you have some feature request, make sure to create a separate issue for it, I just see "work as drop-in replacement" in the issue tracker, but there are suggestions here like a short flag for sorting by mtime that likely have a harder time being picked up by contributors from not having their own issue

> Our plan is to introduce a flag that makes eza ls compatible, this is gonna be done after the clap migration

speaking of that if anyone wanna help review it as its a long standing pr we will accept the help

I'm a yet another `-t` flag user. I went with a script by @kesor:
- https://github.com/eza-community/eza/issues/980#issuecomment-2499761779

1. save to `~/.local/bin/eza-ls`, make file executable
2. I modified `eza-ls` to remove `/usr/bin` from final exec, mine is installed by brew to `/opt/homebrew/bin/eza`
3. ensure `~/.local/bin` is in `$PATH`
4. add `alias ls=eza-ls` to `.zshrc`
5. the rest of `ls` based aliases continue to work

-lrt a gazillion times for me, too.  Muscle memory.

I am removing my alias ls=‘eza’

I will revisit when you fix this.

It’s not drop in replacement as advertized…

Let X be the answer to the puzzle and Y be any string (possibly X).

issueDTO.title: feat: display link to ingested repository in the frontend
issueDTO.description:
When users ingest a repository through the web interface, the results page doesn't provide an easy way to navigate back to the original repository. 
Adding a prominent link to the source repository would improve the user experience and provide context.

Let's discuss the possible UI for this button in this Issue before assigning the Issue to someone
comments:
Hello, I am available to work on this task.
I suggest adding a simple button labeled “View Original Repository” at the top of the results page, opening the repository in a new tab.
I look forward to feedback on this proposal to proceed.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/572fe416-b9e4-4d3a-8986-d121cf0266ef)

@nsancheznez Here's a mockup of what I was thinking

I feel like it's hard to give it a full-size button in the result section because it would give a lot of importance to a button that will be used marginaly


So either a full-size button in the form section (option 1) or a subtle link in the Summary section (option 2)
What do you think?

Hi, I'm Luis Carrión. I'm a front-end UI/UX developer with experience in Next.js, TypeScript, Shadcn, Zustand, TailwindCSS, among others. I'd love to take on this problem. I've done similar work on kindfi and StarkFinder projects. Example: StarkFinder landing page https://github.com/Shonen-Labs/StarkFinder/pull/86 You can view it online at: https://stark-finder-mq45.vercel.app/ I think I could make the button go next to Summary. Look at the image:

@luighis Thanks for your input but here's what I think: those buttons represent the most important actions in the UI, and they are easily visible, that's why I would like to very cautiously use them to avoid cluttering the interface with too many buttons of equal importance

I think we shoud find something a bit more subtle

> ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/572fe416-b9e4-4d3a-8986-d121cf0266ef)
> 
> [@nsancheznez](https://github.com/nsancheznez) Here's a mockup of what I was thinking
> 
> I feel like it's hard to give it a full-size button in the result section because it would give a lot of importance to a button that will be used marginaly
> 
> So either a full-size button in the form section (option 1) or a subtle link in the Summary section (option 2) What do you think?

I agree with your point — a full-size button in the results section might be too visually heavy for something that's not a primary action.
I'm leaning toward Option 2, with a small visual tweak: something like bold or underline styling could make the link slightly more noticeable without overpowering the design.

issueDTO.title: upper_case_acronyms complains about full-capital identifiers
issueDTO.description:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->
Lint name: upper_case_acronyms


I tried this code:

```rust
pub enum DIR {}
```
`Checks for camel case name containing a capitalized acronym.` but there is no camel-case here, it's literally all uppercase, not sure why this triggers here then....

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_END -->
<!-- TRIAGEBOT_END -->
comments: There is no way the lint can tell if you're writing an acronym in camel case or one word in uppercase. According to the API guidelines, enum names should be in "UpperCamelCase" and the lint assumes that you're sticking to those guidelines.
If the lint can't be sure that something is a TP and not a FP, I would rather have it not emit anything because FPs are generally more annoying than FNs.

This lint is about enforcing a rule in the [naming guidelines](https://rust-lang.github.io/api-guidelines/naming.html#casing-conforms-to-rfc-430-c-case). It's enabled by default because projects should follow the guidelines. Projects that are using their own naming standard (for some reason) should just allow this lint.

That warning is correct in every project that follows the Rust style convention that enums are in UpperCamelCase.

The lint is right, but it's reasoning is wrong. The lint name and/or message could be improved so that there is no assumption that "DIR" is an acronym. It could instead say

> Names should be camel-cased and acronyms should not be capitalized after the first letter.

Is it clippy's responsibility to enforce these kinds of formatting guidelines? I don't see any other rules concerning camel or snake case enforcement, and I would expect this to be a rustfmt warning in similar situations (eg "structure field `FIELD` should have a snake case name" for struct fields). I am getting this warning for enum variants, which is not only confusing since I am also not using acronyms, but I think also wrong because enum variants can be considered to be constants, which is why I am ALLCAPSing mine. It doesn't seem right to be encouraged to rewrite enums as a list of constants to dodge this rule.

> Is it clippy's responsibility to enforce these kinds of formatting guidelines?

It's not formatting. It's naming. Those are API Guidelines; not formatting guidelines.

> I don't see any other rules concerning camel or snake case enforcement

The other lints are in rustc itself. See [non-snake-case](https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustc/lints/listing/warn-by-default.html#non-snake-case) for example.
Sorry, naming - but that's my question, is it clippy's responsibility to enforce naming conventions if it's usually rustc's responsibility?
I would like to work on this issue. Could you please assign it to me?
@rustbot claim

repository.description: A bunch of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code. Book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/clippy/
repository.name: rust-clippy

summary.main: Lint name: upper_case_acronyms complains about full-capital identifiers
summary.validationOrRequirement: According to the API guidelines, enum names should be in 'UpperCamelCase' and the lint assumes that you're sticking to those guidelines.
summary.attemptedFixes: The lint can't be sure that something is a TP and not a FP, I would rather have it not emit anything because FPs are generally more annoying than FNs.
summary.otherNotes: The lint is right, but it's reasoning is wrong. The lint name and/or message could be improved so that there is no assumption that 'DIR' is an acronym. It could instead say > Names should be camel-cased and acronyms should not be capitalized after the first letter.
